captions.text:
Chatzi is a two year old rescue Bengal, and
ever since we got him, he's been fascinated

by water. We'd heard that Bengals are not
afraid of water like domestic cats, so we
ran a bath for him!

It's not that he's desperately thirsty, as
there are 4 or 5 bowls of water around the
house, he just loves interesting water!

As you can see, he's a noisy little puss that
loves the sound of his own voice, and drinking
is not going to stop him!

the water gets deeper, and he's not at all
bothered that the water goes over his paws

Theres just no end to how weird his drinking
exploits get!

we wondered how deep the water could get before
he'd have enough of water time, although he

seemed to enjoy the spashing water less. You
can see him turning his ears away to stop

stray splashes going in, and then you see
the now famous Bengal behavour of scraping

away at the surface of the water, instinctive
wild cat behaviour to clear away any leaves
or other debris.

And there he stays, up to his heels in cold
water, happily drinking away.

We even put a rubber duckie to see if this
was play behaviour, but he seemed very intent

on just drinking until the water went away,
and then he wanted playtime!

This is serious stuff - he's focussed, and
not going to be distracted by anything! oh!
Shiny thing!
Bath time's over and playtime starts.

Subscribe to our channel for more observation
and commentary on the fascinating and bizzare
world of cat behaviour!

title: Bengal Cat loves a bath in water

comments.text:
All cats prefer running water. In the wild it is usually cleaner and safer. 
I used to buy goldfish and put them in the tub for my Bengals. I gave the 
fish things to hide under. The bengals went wild. Unfortunately they did 
catch a goldfish or two so I quit this fun play time.﻿

comments.text:
Its probably because he likes to drink cool fresh water rather than 
luke-warm stagnant water that's been sitting in bowls all day collecting 
dust.  I don't blame him, I'd be the same.﻿
comments.author: EASYTIGER10

comments.text:
+TheMaul3r_Real 1) Water straight out of a tap has more dissolved oxygen in 
it
2) Being in pipes means it is very unlikely to have serious bacterial 
contamination
3) Water out of a tap is not full of airborne dust, or other organic matter
4) Water out of the cold tap is well below room temperature making it a) 
less suitable for bacterial growth and b) more refreshing

So tap water IS different to stuff sitting in bowls all day. And I said 
"stagnant" not "stale"  Water most definitely can become contaminated! 
 Milliona are killed by it every year!
comments.author: EASYTIGER10

comments.text: +TheMaul3r_Real stop being an idiot.
comments.author: Moonie TREOS

comments.text:
i've read that wild cats prefer running water like rivers over stagnant 
water, because stagnant water has a bigger risk of getting them sick 
(infections). house cats also have that instinct. a lot of house cats like 
drinking out of the tap for that reason :)
comments.author: AIIUserNamesInvalid

comments.text:
I used to have a Korat that loved water. He used to run in the yard and 
chase the sprinkler. On occasion, he'd jump in the shower with me and as 
long as he didn't get sprayed in the face, he was perfectly happy. When he 
was a kitten, he would only drink running water - he refused to drink from 
a bowl. As he got older, that habit faded and he would drink from the bowl. 
But turn on any tap, and he was there like a flash of lightning, sticking 
his head in for a drink.﻿
comments.author: Harold Lloyd

comments.text:
My Maincoon Bengal mix cat would always go in and roll around in the water 
left on the floor after we showered. Getting all kinds of things wet 
afterwards.﻿
comments.author: David Stenström

comments.text:
I think my cat is a Bengal or Egyptian Mau mix because he loves water.  We 
bought him a drinking fountain and he loves putting his paws in the water 
and taking a drink right from the fountain.  Also given the chance he will 
jump in the tub during a shower and sit on the edge or jump in the water.﻿

comments.text:
You are welcome :) I am looking for one to adopt atm. It´ll be my third 
pound cat, in succession alas. However, this time, I find myself 
considering adding a second one later. A kitten as a 2nd would be best I 
suppose? I would think two adults is much harder, even if you try to find 
compatible minds.

The way you did it was really sensitive to the species and impressive. I 
find myself paying much more attention to cats among themselves as well. 
Fun to see, and yet so educational. And people are absolutely right, you 
have a wonderful voice. Would love to see more of their capers :)
